Let's use pedogate as an example (whether you believe in the theories or not doesn't matter for this). An ideal journalist would look at the claims being made, do some investigating, and then report on exactly what they found without any theorizing or biased assumptions. However, you might notice that many MSM articles, including even the wikipedia entry, are more than happy to declare the issue "debunked." Many journalists report with very high confidence that there is no truth to any of it. And how are they so sure? Well, a journalist from the New York Times had an interview with James Alefantis, the owner of Comet Ping Pong Pizza, the man at the center of the conspiracy theory, and asked him if any of it was true. And lo and behold, he said no. From the NYT: None of it was true. While Mr. Alefantis has some prominent Democratic friends in Washington and was a supporter of Mrs. Clinton, he has never met her, does not sell or abuse children, and is not being investigated by law enforcement for any of these claims. Now, maybe you agree with the NYT article, maybe you don't. But think about what is happening here: a journalist is investigating a claim that someone is a trafficker of children. They investigate this claim by going directly to the person being accused, asking them if it is true, and then blindly accepting his answer. And what further backs up Mr. Alefantis' story? The fact that the police aren't investigating the claims! If you told me that someone may have committed a crime and I responded by saying "I know he didn't do it" you may very well ask "But how do you know?" And if my answer was "Because I asked him. Also, the police didn't ask him yet." Would you accept that as good enough? Is that "ideal journalism" at work? How is the fact that an official investigation hasn't been done proof that there is no crime? If anything it is proof that nobody really knows.
